channel.title: mysql on Roy Tang
channel.description: Recent content in mysql on Roy Tang

item.title: Reply to 'how to detect incoming chat message?' on stackoverflow at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/3146067/how-to-detect-incoming-chat-message:
item.author: hello@roytang.net (Roy Tang)
item.description:
Reply to 'how to detect incoming chat message?' on stackoverflow at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/3146067/how-to-detect-incoming-chat-message:

You have to use polling, but you can use a technique called Comet which involves long-polling, i.e. sending out an ajax request that will be held by the server until a chat request comes in.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comet_(programming))

item.title: Reply to 'Mysql: Which to use when: drop table, truncate table, delete from table' on stackoverflow at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2012974/mysql-which-to-use-when-drop-table-truncate-table-delete-from-table:
item.author: hello@roytang.net (Roy Tang)
item.description:
Reply to 'Mysql: Which to use when: drop table, truncate table, delete from table' on stackoverflow at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2012974/mysql-which-to-use-when-drop-table-truncate-table-delete-from-table:

In addition to the answers above, on Oracle RDBMS, “delete” is a transaction that can be rolled back if you didn’t commit. “Truncate” cannot.

item.title: Reply to 'Is it really no solution to update multiple records in MySQL?' on stackoverflow at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1871131/is-it-really-no-solution-to-update-multiple-records-in-mysql:
item.author: hello@roytang.net (Roy Tang)
item.description:
Reply to 'Is it really no solution to update multiple records in MySQL?' on stackoverflow at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1871131/is-it-really-no-solution-to-update-multiple-records-in-mysql:

ts_1, ts_2, ts_3, etc. are different fields on the same table? There’s no way to do that with a single statement.
